entry.title: Understanding Seamless Planning
entry.content:
Introduction to Seamless Planning  

Seamless Planning is a new integration paradigm between SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) and SAP Datasphere that unifies planning logic with enterprise-grade data storage and governance. It allows SAC to remain the planning experience and calculation engine while Datasphere becomes the authoritative and governed persistence layer for plan data and master data. This means planning teams can reuse planning data across analytics, data transformation pipelines, and operational applications‚Äîwithout duplicating or exporting data outside of SAC. Modelers can build SAC planning models that physically store their transactional data and public dimensions inside Datasphere. They also have control over whether planning artifacts from SAC are exposed in Datasphere for reuse across Spaces or downstream analytic models.

Technical Architecture

  • Model Metadata & Planning Logic: Planning calculations, version management, and data actions remain defined inside SAC.
  • Fact Data & Dimensions Stored in Datasphere: The planning model‚Äôs fact tables and public dimensions are persisted in Datasphere to enable governed reuse and enterprise distribution.
  • Data Exposure from SAC to Datasphere: SAC can expose selected planning objects as read-only Datasphere artifacts, enabling modelers to use these objects in Data Builder or transform them into Analytical Models.

Key Benefits

  • Unified Planning Data: Centralized storage of plan facts and dimensions in Datasphere ensures consistency across systems and workflows.
  • Direct Persistence to Datasphere: Changes made in SAC planning flows are instantly reflected in Datasphere fact tables‚Äîno manual exports required.
  • Optimized SAC Resource Usage: Offloading data storage to Datasphere reduces SAC‚Äôs memory and storage footprint.
  • Enterprise Reusability & Governance: Datasphere‚Äôs modeling and transformation extend to planning data, enabling secure and scalable reuse in the form of analytic models.

This approach eliminates data silos, reduces duplication, and empowers organizations to operationalize planning data across their digital landscape‚Äîwhile preserving SAC‚Äôs rich planning experience at the front end.

Prerequisites for Seamless Planning

Before configuring or deploying planning models from SAC to Datasphere, ensure the following system prerequisites are met.

1. SAC Tenant Must Be Running on SAP HANA Cloud

  • SAC must be provisioned on SAP HANA Cloud infrastructure.
  • To verify: Navigate to System ‚Üí About in SAC and confirm the HANA Cloud version is listed.
  • This ensures compatibility with Datasphere‚Äôs storage and modeling architecture.

 2.  Tenant Co-Location and 1:1 Linkage

  • Both SAC and Datasphere tenants must reside in the same SAP data center region.
  • A 1:1 tenant relationship is required‚Äîeach SAC tenant must be linked to a single Datasphere tenant.
  • This linkage enables SAC to persist planning data directly into Datasphere spaces.
  • This can be done in System √† Administration √† Tenant Links in both SAP Analytics Cloud and SAP Datasphere.

3. Consistent Identity Provider (IdP) Configuration

  • It is strongly recommended that both tenants use the same SAML-based Identity Provider (IdP).
  • This ensures consistent user identity mapping across SAC and Datasphere.

4. System Owner Credentials on Both Tenants

  • The tenant linkage process requires authentication using a system owner account on both SAC and Datasphere.
  • This account must have administrative privileges to authorize cross-tenant integration.

5. User Role Assignment in Datasphere Space

    • SAC users who need to create, edit, or expose planning models must be granted appropriate space-level roles in Datasphere.
    • Without these roles, SAC will not be able to write data or expose model objects to the designated Datasphere space.

If any of the above conditions are not met, then Datasphere will not appear as a selectable data storage location in SAC. The  SAP Knowledge Base Article 3515100 highlights certain errors along with their corresponding workarounds.

Workflow for Seamless Planning

1. Create a New Model in SAC: While creating a new Model in SAC, there is an option available to specify the Data Storage Location as a Space within SAP Datasphere.

2. Configure Dimensions and Measures:  The model created with Datasphere persistence layer is created as a Planning Measure based model by default and the data storage location is Datasphere Space as shown in model details.

3. Expose to Datasphere: There is also an additional option in the Model Details to expose the underlying fact table in the chosen Datasphere space. What gets created in Datasphere: When a SAC planning model is configured to store data in Datasphere:

4. What gets created in Datasphere: When a SAC planning model is configured to store data in Datasphere:

  • A Fact object (read-only) becomes visible in the Datasphere Space.
  • A corresponding physical table (sap.sac.<GUID>) is created to store transactional planning data.
  • Any public dimensions used in the model are created in Datasphere as dimension tables and remain shareable across Space.

5. Execute Planning scenarios in SAC: With the new model now exposed in Datasphere, key planning scenarios can continue to be executed within SAC exactly as before. Seamless Planning does not alter the way SAC planning processes run; it simply extends the option to persist and integrate data through Datasphere while maintaining the familiar SAC planning experience.

  • Create and Execute a Data Action: Develop a Data Action in SAC to update planning data. Once executed, publish the updated data back to Datasphere to ensure synchronization across platforms.
  • Conduct Actual vs Plan Analysis: Utilize SAC's analytical capabilities to compare actual performance against planned figures. This enables variance analysis and supports informed decision-making.
  • Extend Modelling in Datasphere: Build custom calculations directly within SAP Datasphere using the exposed model. Create a dedicated view and Analytical Model on top of these calculations, then visualize the results seamlessly in SAC for enhanced planning insights.

Important Considerations

SAP is actively working to reduce the space dependency in future releases, for latest updates please refer the SAP Roadmap Explorer and the help guide.

  • Cross-Model Planning Constraints: Currently all models involved in cross-model planning operations‚Äîsuch as a data action, cross-model copy step must be in the same Datasphere space.
  • Shared Public Dimensions:  Sharing public dimensions across multiple models is only supported when both the models and the associated public dimensions are deployed within the same SAP Datasphere space. The same requirement applies to currency rate tables, which must reside in the same space to be referenced across models.
  • Hierarchies:  Hierarchies defined in SAP Analytics Cloud are not exposed to SAP Datasphere. If hierarchical structures are required for modeling or reporting, Datasphere modelers must reconstruct these hierarchies natively within Datasphere, ensuring alignment with the underlying data model and semantic layer.

Seamless Planning in BDC

SAP is introducing a unified enterprise planning paradigm through SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC). This represents the next stage in the evolution of Seamless Planning, where planning activities are connected, real-time, and driven by trusted operational data‚Äîeliminating the traditional ‚Äúexport, transform, and import‚Äù workflow. Because SAC and Datasphere are core components of BDC, seamless planning is highly relevant in this context and establishes the foundation for deep integration of planning data within the BDC environment. Looking ahead, BDC has the potential to further enrich seamless planning by:

  • Supporting planning-enabled intelligent applications that combine analytics with actionable planning workflows.
  • Extending planning architectures to include platforms such as SAP Databricks.
  • Enabling the consumption of data products directly within planning processes, ensuring governed, reusable, and scalable planning assets.

To understand Seamless Planning in context of Business Data Cloud, please refer to this blog.

entry.title: SAP RPT-1 Context Model vs. Training Classical Models: The Models Battle (Python Hands-on)
entry.content:
üí•The Models Battle

Predictive modeling is becoming a built-in capability across SAP, improving how teams handle forecasting, pricing, and planning. Many SAP professionals, however, aren‚Äôt machine-learning specialists, and traditional models often demand extensive setup, tuning, and repeated training, which slows down new ideas.

SAP RPT-1 offers a simpler path. It‚Äôs a pretrained model from SAP, also available in an OSS version, that lets developers and consultants produce predictions with far less technical effort, no deep ML background required.

I've explored SAP RPT-1 hands-on, comparing it with traditional regressors using Python and a real public vehicles price dataset. 

Goal: To see (as a non Data Scientist) how SAP RPT-1 behaves in practice, what advantages and limits it shows, and when it could make sense in a predictive scenario.

Usually for real-world scenario, the right approach would be consume the SAP RPT-1 though the available and simplified API, but for studies proposal and fair comparision over othe traditional ML models, the OSS fits perfectly for it:

ü§î SAP RPT-1 vs Traditional Machine Learning - Core Differences

Before diving into the code, let‚Äôs quickly revisit how traditional ML models work:

  • Training-based models like Random Forest, LightGBM, and Linear Regression learn patterns directly from data. 
  • They require hundreds or thousands of examples to tune their internal parameters.
  • Their performance depends heavily on data quantity and quality.
  • The more relevant examples they see, the smarter they get.

On the other hand, SAP RPT-1 follows a different philosophy. It‚Äôs part of the RPT (Representational Predictive Transformer) family, pretrained on a wide variety of business and contextual data. This means:

  • You don‚Äôt "train" it in the traditional sense. Instead, it uses context embeddings to predict outcomes.
  • It can be used immediately, even with smaller datasets.
  • The OSS version allows developers to experiment directly in Python.
  • No special SAP backend required.

Outcome: Traditional ML models learn from high amount of data. SAP RPT-1 already knows how to deal with small context amount of data.

üñ• The Experiment - Setup & Dataset 

Spoiler
Don't worry on "playing puzzles" copying + pasting code below. The full version is available for download at end!

To make this comparison tangible, I built a simple yet realistic Python experiment to predict vehicle selling prices using a public dataset containing car attributes like make, model, year, transmission, and mileage.

Why vehicle pricing? Because it‚Äôs an intuitive example where both traditional machine learning and pretrained AI models can be applie, and it helps visualize how prediction quality evolves as the sample size grows.

This entire analysis runs on a local Python environment with the following stack:

import os
import gc
import warnings
import pandas as pd
import numpy as np
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
from datetime import datetime
from sklearn.model_selection import train_test_split
from sklearn.metrics import r2_score
from sklearn.ensemble import RandomForestRegressor
from sklearn.preprocessing import LabelEncoder
from sklearn.linear_model import LinearRegression
from sap_rpt_oss import SAP_RPT_OSS_Regressor
import lightgbm as lgb
  • pandas and numpy for data manipulation
  • scikit-learn for classical ML regressors (Random Forest, Linear Regression)
  • LightGBM for gradient boosting comparison
  • sap_rpt_oss ‚Äî the open-source Python version of SAP‚Äôs RPT-1 model
  • matplotlib for all visualizations

SAP RPT-1 OSS can be downloaded installed following official Hugging Face: https://huggingface.co/SAP/sap-rpt-1-oss?library=sap-rpt-1-oss . Python can be installed with executable download on Windows, or via Home Brew for Mac and apt commands for Linux. Libraries dependencies can be downloaded with pip commands. Googling it may not be a road blocker.

We use a sample vehicle sales dataset. The complete file is about to 88Mb but for such experiment a restricted sample of 20k as it's more than enough to prove our the concept, still it's faster and consuming less computing resources.

FeatureDescription
yearVehicle model year
makeBrand (e.g., Toyota, Ford, BMW)
modelSpecific model name
bodyType (SUV, Sedan, etc.)
transmissionGear type
odometerVehicle mileage
color, interiorVisual attributes
sellingpriceThe target variable to predict

üìä Dataset Download: https://www.kaggle.com/datasets/syedanwarafridi/vehicle-sales-data?resource=download 

The dataset is loaded and preprocessed in a few simple steps:

df = pd.read_csv("car_prices.csv").sample(n=20000, random_state=42)

# Fill missing values for categorical columns
fill_defaults = {
    'make': 'Other', 'model': 'Other', 'color': 'Other',
    'interior': 'Unknown', 'body': 'Unknown', 'transmission': 'Unknown'
}
for col, val in fill_defaults.items():
    df[col] = df[col].fillna(val)

X = df[["year", "make", "model", "body", "transmission", "odometer", "color", "interior"]]
y = df["sellingprice"]

At this point, the stage is set:

  • The data is clean.
  • The environment is ready.
  • All models, traditionals and SAP RPT-1, are ready to be tested under identical conditions.

ü§ñ Training the Models - Three different ones

With the dataset ready, the next step is to run each model under the same conditions: same features, same target, same train/test split and same random seed. This ensures the comparison is fair and repeatable.

We evaluate prediction performance using R¬≤ (coefficient of determination), which indicates how much of the price variation the model can explain (1.0 = perfect prediction).

Training Model #1 - Random Forest

Random Forest is often the first model used in tabular ML. It works by creating many decision trees and averaging their predictions. Before training, categorical variables need to be label-encoded into numbers, a common requirement for classical ML models:

def train_random_forest(X, y):
    X = X.copy()
    cat_cols = ["make", "model", "body", "transmission", "color", "interior"]
    le = LabelEncoder()

    for col in cat_cols:
        X[col] = le.fit_transform(X[col].astype(str).fillna("Unknown"))

    X_train, X_test, y_train, y_test = train_test_split(
        X, y, test_size=default_test_size, random_state=42
    )

    model = RandomForestRegressor(
        n_estimators=150, max_depth=20, random_state=42, n_jobs=-1
    )

    try:
        model.fit(X_train, y_train)
        preds = model.predict(X_test)
        r2 = r2_score(y_test, preds)
    except Exception as e:
        preds, r2 = np.zeros_like(y_test), 0

    return [preds, r2, y_test]

Training Model #2 - LightGBM

LightGBM is one of the most powerful models for tabular data. Unlike Random Forest (many independent trees), LightGBM builds trees sequentially, each correcting the errors of the previous one. It supports categorical features natively, which simplifies preprocessing.

def train_lightgbm(X, y):
    X = X.copy()
    cat_cols = ["make", "model", "body", "transmission", "color", "interior"]
    for col in cat_cols:
        X[col] = X[col].astype(str).fillna("Unknown").astype("category")

    X_train, X_test, y_train, y_test = train_test_split(
        X, y, test_size=default_test_size, random_state=42
    )

    model = lgb.LGBMRegressor(
        n_estimators=500, learning_rate=0.05, num_leaves=31,
        subsample=0.8, colsample_bytree=0.8, random_state=42
    )

    try:
        model.fit(X_train, y_train, categorical_feature=cat_cols)
        preds = model.predict(X_test)
        r2 = r2_score(y_test, preds)
    except Exception:
        preds, r2 = np.zeros_like(y_test), 0

    return [preds, r2, y_test]

Training Model #3 - Linear Regression

Not fancy and even not complex, Linear Regression provides a baseline that shows: ‚ÄúIf the relationship between attributes and price is roughly linear, how well can a simple model perform?‚Äù

def train_linear_model(X, y):
    X = X.copy()
    cat_cols = ["make", "model", "body", "transmission", "color", "interior"]
    for col in cat_cols:
        X[col] = LabelEncoder().fit_transform(X[col].astype(str).fillna("Unknown"))

    X_train, X_test, y_train, y_test = train_test_split(
        X, y, test_size=default_test_size, random_state=42
    )

    model = LinearRegression()
    X_train = X_train.fillna(X_train.mean(numeric_only=True))
    X_test = X_test.fillna(X_test.mean(numeric_only=True))

    try:
        model.fit(X_train, y_train)
        preds = model.predict(X_test)
        r2 = r2_score(y_test, preds)
    except Exception:
        preds, r2 = np.zeros_like(y_test), 0

    return [preds, r2, y_test]

üèÅ SAP RPT-1 OSS: Context Model

This is where things get interesting. SAP RPT-1 does not rely on learning patterns from the dataset. Instead, it uses a pretrained transformer architecture to infer relationships directly through context embeddings. Lean and simple, "for non-Data Science PhD":

def train_sap_rpt1(X, y):
    X_train, X_test, y_train, y_test = train_test_split(
        X, y, test_size=default_test_size, random_state=42
    )

    model = SAP_RPT_OSS_Regressor(max_context_size=8192, bagging=8)
    model.fit(X_train, y_train)

    preds = model.predict(X_test)
    r2 = r2_score(y_test, preds)

    return [preds, r2, y_test]

üîé Running Experiments at Multiple Sample Sizes

This section breaks down how the iterative experiment loop works, why the SAP RPT-1 OSS model has a max-context limit, and how performance changes as we scale up the dataset. By running the same models across several sample sizes, we can see where traditional ML shines, where RPT-1 stays competitive, and how both behave as the data grows.

sample_sizes = np.linspace(50, len(X), 200, dtype=int)
results, max_r2_rpt1, max_sample_rpt1 = [], 0, 0

for n in sample_sizes:
    idx = np.random.choice(len(X), n, replace=False)
    X_sample, y_sample = X.iloc[idx], y.iloc[idx]


    # SAP RPT-1 OSS (limited sample size)
    if n <= rpt1_limit:
        rpt_res = train_sap_rpt1(X_sample, y_sample)
        fn = plot_predictions(rpt_res[2], rpt_res[0], rpt_res[1], "SAP_RPT1", n)
        video_frames["SAP_RPT1"].append(fn)
        r2_rpt1 = rpt_res[1]
        max_r2_rpt1 = max(max_r2_rpt1, r2_rpt1)
    else:
        r2_rpt1 = max_r2_rpt1
        if max_sample_rpt1 == 0:
            max_sample_rpt1 = n

    # Train and plot models
    rf_res = train_random_forest(X_sample, y_sample)
    fn = plot_predictions(rf_res[2], rf_res[0], rf_res[1], "RandomForest", n)
    video_frames["RandomForest"].append(fn)

    lgb_res = train_lightgbm(X_sample, y_sample)
    fn = plot_predictions(lgb_res[2], lgb_res[0], lgb_res[1], "LightGBM", n)
    video_frames["LightGBM"].append(fn)

    lin_res = train_linear_model(X_sample, y_sample)
    fn = plot_predictions(lin_res[2], lin_res[0], lin_res[1], "LinearModel", n)
    video_frames["LinearModel"].append(fn)

    results.append((n, rf_res[1], r2_rpt1, lgb_res[1], lin_res[1]))

    # Early stop if traditional model reaches SAP RPT-1
    if rf_res[1] >= max_r2_rpt1 or lgb_res[1] >= max_r2_rpt1 or lin_res[1] >= max_r2_rpt1:
        break
    gc.collect()

This loop compares SAP RPT-1 OSS with traditional ML models as sample sizes increase. Each iteration randomly selects a subset of the data and trains all models on the same slice for a fair comparison. SAP RPT-1 can only run up to its max-context limit, so once the sample size exceeds that threshold, it stops retraining and simply carries forward its best R¬≤. The traditional models continue training at every step. The loop ends early when any traditional model matches or surpasses RPT-1‚Äôs best score, making the experiment efficient while showing how performance evolves as data grows.

üîö Conclusion and Final Thoughts

 SAP RPT-1 OSS stands out because it performs well with small datasets, requires minimal code, and can generate useful predictions with just an API call and a bit of context. This makes it ideal for jump-starting predictive use cases early on, delivering fast business value without a full ML pipeline. Traditional models, however, still shine when projects mature, data grows, and fine-tuned control becomes important. It‚Äôs not about choosing one over the other, but understanding where each approach brings the most value.

 Aspect SAP RPT-1 OSS Traditional ML (RF, LGBM, Linear)
Data RequirementsLow (performs well with small samples)Medium/High (performance scales with data
Setup EffortMinimal (API call + context)Higher (preprocessing, encoding, tuning)
Training ProcessNone (pretrained context model)Full training pipeline required
Speed to InsightsVery fastModerate to slow
Best Use CaseEarly-stage predictive cases, quick baselinesMature pipelines, high control and customization
FlexibilityLimited tuning / plug-and-playHighly customizable
Business ValueImmediate, fast, accessibleStrong when optimized and scaled

This experiment highlights a simple truth: SAP RPT-1 isn‚Äôt here to replace traditional ML, it jump-starts it. With a pretrained, context-driven approach, RPT-1 delivers fast, reliable insights with very little data and almost no setup. Traditional models still excel in mature, data-rich scenarios, but RPT-1 shines as a rapid accelerator and early-value generator inside SAP landscapes.

üí¨Open for Exchange

If you're testing RPT-1, exploring predictive cases, or want the full code, feel free to reach out.
Happy to connect, compare experiences, and push this topic forward together.

entry.title: Link SAC and SAP DSP tenants via Formation to Schedule a SAC Story Based on SAP DSP Live Connection
entry.content:
Create a Formation to Integrate with SAP Analytics Cloud

Prerequisites

  • You are an SAP global account administrator, or you are a system landscape administrator.

  • SAP Analytics Cloud can run on Hana 2.0 or HANA Cloud.

  • Both SAP Analytics Cloud and SAP Datasphere tenants must be located in the same data center and deployed in the same landscape. SAP data centers are not in the scope.

  • Both SAP Analytics Cloud and SAP Datasphere tenants must use the same identity provider (IdP) and the same subject name identifier.

  • Ensure the relevant SAP Analytics Cloud and SAP Datasphere tenants or systems in your landscape are available to be integrated in a formation.

  • Context

    A formation is created in SAP BTP cockpit in the System Landscape section of your global account. The formation identifies the systems that can connect with your SAP Analytics Cloud tenant.

    Formations enable the automated integration between a set of your provisioned SAP systems.

    Procedure

    1. In the SAP BTP cockpit System Landscape  Systems page, browse the systems in your customer system landscape.
      Every SAP Analytics Cloud system and SAP Datasphere system you are going to include in this formation must not be apart of another formation. The system landscape features auto-discovered systems in the list.
      • Note

        if a given system is missing on the Systems page, it may be associated with a different customer ID on the SAP BTP global account you're working in. In this case you need to add the system manually, and then register it. For more information, see Adding, Registering, and Deregistering Systems.

    2. Go to System Landscape   Formations. Select Create Formation.
      1. In the General Information step, enter a descriptive formation name.
      2. In the Formation Type drop-down menu, select Integration with SAP Analytics Cloud.
    3. Select Next Step.
    4. In the Include Systems step, select the SAP Datasphere tenant and SAP Analytics Cloud tenant you want to link with.
    5. Select Next Step.
    6. Review your selections and create the formation.

    Results

    The formation appears under your list of formations and a Ready success message is shown.

    Delete a Formation in SAP BTP Cockpit

    Context

    When you delete a formation, the following happens. Both SAP Analytics Cloud and SAP Datasphere tenants will be excluded from the formation. Then, the subaccount is unassigned. Finally, the SAP Analytics Cloud formation is removed from the Formations page completely.

    Procedure

    1. In the SAP BTP cockpit go to System Landscape  Formations.
    2. Select the formation of SAP Analytics Cloud that you want to remove.
    3. Select Delete at the top-right of the formation.

    Recreation of Formation

    When formation is recreated the scheduling feature will be enabled again. The functionalities will continue to work as they were before the deletion. For scheduling, UCL formation will only provide enablement of tunneled connections.

    As a next step to create Tunnel connection and perform scheduling of SAC story based on DSP live connectivity please follow the help document. 

    https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_ANALYTICS_CLOUD/18850a0e13944f53aa8a8b7c094ea29e/1c4c615f5d7f4b78a5ae681759a55650.html?version=2025.23

entry.title: Scheduling SAP Analytics Cloud Stories Based on SAP Datasphere Live Connections
entry.content:
Overview

(Available Starting QRC4 2025)

Scheduled publications are an important feature in SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC), enabling organizations to distribute stories at regular intervals for offline access over email email delivery.

As SAP Datasphere continues to be the strategic data foundation for SAP customers, many organizations rely extensively on live connections between SAC and Datasphere. Starting with SAP Analytics Cloud QRC4 2025, customers can now schedule publications for stories built on SAP Datasphere live connections.

This capability is supported for:

  • SAP Analytics cloud and SAP Datasphere on BDC Tenant
  • Standalone (non-BDC) SAP Analytics Cloud and SAP Datasphere Tenant

Prerequisites

To schedule a story based on a Datasphere live connection, the story must use an SAP Datasphere Tunnel Connection.

Creating a Datasphere Tunnel Connection

A Tunnel Connection can be created only when SAP Analytics Cloud and SAP Datasphere tenants are ‚Äúdeep linked.‚Äù Deep linking ensures seamless authentication, metadata access, and cross-system operations.

Deep linking configurations:

  • Option 1 ‚Äî In BDC tenant where SAP Analytics Cloud and SAP Datasphere tenants are linked via BDC formation (Recommended)
  • Option 2 ‚Äî In SAP Analytics Cloud tenant and SAP Datasphere tenant (Non BDC) are linked via UCL formation.  (Recommended) - Refer to blog Link SAC and SAP DSP tenants via Formation to Schedule a SAC Story Based on SAP DSP Live Connection 
  • Option 3 ‚Äî SAP Analytics Cloud and SAP Datasphere Tenant are linked for seamless planning as below 

     

Once any one of the above configurations is done, In SAP Analytics Cloud tenant, you can create a SAP Datasphere Tunnel connection using below step

  • From the side navigation, choose Connections  
  • Click Add + Connection
  • Expand Connect to Live Data and select SAP Datasphere.
  • In the dialog, enter a name and description for your connection.
  • From the Connection Type drop-down list, select Tunnel
    • Tunnel connection type is mandatory if you plan to use this Scheduled Publications using the Datasphere Live connection.
    • For tunnel connections, ensure both SAC and Datasphere users use the same Identity Provider (IdP)

Note: In QRC4.2025, you have an option to create new Tunnel connection, however, you will not be able to convert existing SAP Datasphere Direct connection to Tunnel connection. However, if you are on Fast track tenant and SAP Analytics Cloud version 2025.23 or beyond then you can edit Direct connection to Tunnel Connection. If you are on QRC tenant, then this will be available in QRC1.2026

 

Scheduling a Story Based on a Datasphere Live Connection

Once the Tunnel Connection is created and used in the story, it can be scheduled like any other SAC story, with support for email distribution, CSV/Excel/PDF/PowerPoint output, recurrence, dynamic time filters, and personalization.

Conclusion

Starting QRC4 2025, this enhancement supports Scheduling Publication of SAP Analytics Cloud story capabilities for customers using SAP Datasphere with SAP Analytics Cloud.

entry.title: The Added Value of SAP Business Data Cloud with Databricks, Snowflake and MS Fabric
entry.content:
There as been a lot of partnership announcement lately broadening the extend of SAP Business Data Cloud capabilities and integration.

In today‚Äôs multi-platform data landscapes, organizations are increasingly blending SAP and non-SAP data to drive insights, automate decision-making, and accelerate innovation. But combining the trusted semantics of SAP with the scalability and flexibility of modern cloud data platforms is not always straightforward.
This is where SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC)‚Äîpowered by SAP Datasphere‚Äîdelivers extraordinary strategic value. And with BDC connect, SAP takes cross-ecosystem integration even further, enabling a harmonized, governed, bidirectional data fabric that works seamlessly with platforms such as Microsoft Fabric, Snowflake, and Databricks.

Why SAP Business Data Cloud Changes the Game

SAP Business Data Cloud is designed to bridge the historical gap between SAP‚Äôs rich business context and the broader data landscape. It moves beyond simple data replication or extraction: it preserves SAP‚Äôs business semantics, delivers harmonized models, and enables federated consumption with minimal data movement, to take on-time decisions based on data.

Here‚Äôs what makes it transformative:

1. Business-ready data out of the box

SAP systems contain deeply embedded logic‚Äîcurrency conversions, hierarchies, master data relationships, authorizations, time-dependencies‚Äînone of which carry over when raw tables are moved into a data lake or modern warehouse.

Throughts Business Data Cloud, SAP provides out-of-the box Data Products that automatically collects and exposes SAP data with meaning intact, avoiding:

  • custom semantic reconstruction

  • brittle pipelines

  • manual hierarchical transformations

This dramatically reduces time-to-insight for downstream analytics platforms.

2. Governance, lineage, and security at enterprise scale

BDC maintains:

  • end-to-end lineage

  • SAP role-based security

  • metadata enrichment

  • business catalogs

This ensures that downstream platforms consume trusted, governed data, not raw or misinterpreted tables.

How BDC combines with Microsoft Fabric, Snowflake, and Databricks

While SAP Business Data Cloud is a fully standalone powerful platform for data and analytics, customers may have chosen another technology to handle some aspects of their data storage and governance. Providing a partnership with these platforms enables to propose a deep integration within a broader ecosystem.

- SAP Business Data Cloud + Microsoft Fabric

With BDC connect, Fabric can tap directly into SAP semantic models with a zero-copy capabilities enabling to successfully combine SAP and non-SAP data and leverging the existing features of Microfot Fabric.

- SAP Business Data Cloud + Snowflake

Snowflake excels at multi-cloud elasticity, secure data sharing, and workload isolation. BDC complements Snowflake through:

  • SAP-optimized data contracts exposed as Snowflake-ready datasets

  • Replication or federation with preserved semantics

  • Accelerated development of Snowflake Data Cloud applications using SAP-trusted data

Here too, the BDC Connect capabilities enables to do a zero-copy sharing of the data, avoiding data replication and keeping the context of the data..

- SAP Business Data Cloud + Databricks

Databricks is the leader in lakehouse architecture, ML/AI workloads, and open data formats. With BDC:

  • Data scientists gain business-aware SAP data without reverse-engineering SAP logic

  • ML models can be trained on harmonized SAP+non-SAP datasets

  • Semantic consistency is maintained from source to model consumption

  • Unity Catalog benefits from SAP lineage and metadata

BDC connect enables bi-directional zero-copy interoperability, including pushing curated datasets back into analytics or operational systems.

BDC connect: The Integration Accelerator

A core enabler in the ecosystem is BDC connect, providing a streamlined, governed, and high-performance integration zero-copy mechanism between SAP Business Data Cloud and modern data platforms.

With BDC connect, your data platform of choice becomes SAP-aware by design.

To summarize :

BDC ensures your modern data platforms stop treating SAP as just another source, and start treating it as a first-class, business-ready data foundation.

entry.title: Positioning SAP Business Data cloud on SAP Business Technology Platform : Clearing the Confusion
entry.content:
As we all know, with digital transformation and the move toward cloud mindset, clean core, fit-to-standard, and fit-to-suite, the shift to cloud-based business solutions keeps growing. Many of us remember the term introduced around 2011 when the HANA database was introduced  the SAP Business Intelligence portfolio. Over time, this evolved to BW on HANA, BW/4HANA, and then the ERP transition from ECC to S/4HANA.

From my understanding, this Business Intelligence portfolio or SAP BI Suite has also evolved with the adoption of the cloud platform. Now we hear the term SAP Business Suite, which I think is similar to the earlier BI Suite which acts like an umbrella covering the core enterprise applications. This newer SAP Business Suite connects different areas of the business using SAP Cloud ERP and SAP Business Data Cloud, all running on top of SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP).

SAP BTP is known as a platform-as-a-service used to design, build, deploy, and manage end-to-end applications in the cloud. It provides the foundation for integrating, extending, and innovating across SAP and non-SAP systems, so business processes remain connected, flexible, and intelligent.

We are also familiar with the fact that we can view all the services available on BTP through the SAP Discovery Center under different capability areas: App Development, Integration, Data & Analytics and Artificial Intelligence.

If you go to the Discovery Center and look under Data & Analytics, you will see SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) and SAP Datasphere listed there. But when you go to the BTP Cockpit and try to create a service for these applications, you won‚Äôt find them.

And that‚Äôs exactly where the confusion started for me. Because they appear under BTP capabilities, the expectation is that we should be able to create them as services.
But we can‚Äôt and this is where SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC) comes into the picture.

 

 

 

 

 

SAP Business Data Cloud is a SaaS business solution suite built on top of BTP. It uses the underlying BTP data and analytics capabilities like Datasphere and SAC.

To simplify:

  • BDC is not replacing BTP ‚Äî it runs on top of it.
  • BDC is a packaged business solution, not a developer service.
  • You cannot create BDC service on BTP like you create HANA Cloud or Integration Suite.
  • BDC has its own onboarding and tenant provisioning process.

In short, BTP is the platform, and BDC is the ready-to-use data and analytics solution built on that platform.

The next question that popped into my mind, since we cannot create them as services or subscriptions via BTP, how do we access them? We still have a standalone SAC tenant , a standalone Datasphere tenant and we could switch between them easily by linking the tenants. This still works the same.

What changed now is that SAP now sells this as a packaged solution under BDC.
Instead of separate licenses for SAC and Datasphere, BDC combines them into one SaaS package and just one license.

So BTP remains the platform under the hood, while BDC provides the SAAS packaged solution but it is not a BTP service. It has its own onboarding, which I‚Äôll cover in my next blog.

entry.title: Simple understanding of Hierarchies in SAP S/4HANA Embedded Analytics‚Äì Part 1 (Basics)
entry.content:
Accurate CDS hierarchy modeling and understanding is critical for financial reporting and operational analytics. Without well-defined hierarchies, drill-down analysis and aggregated insights become challenging. This blog demystifies hierarchy concepts in SAP S/4HANA Embedded Analytics and shows how they power SAC,Multidimensiona Reports , AFO and Datasphere scenarios.This blog will give you the basic understanding of Hierarchies in CDS Views (S4 Hana)

What This Blog Covers

  • Common hierarchy terminologies
  • Types of hierarchies in CDS Views
  • Standard hierarchies in S/4HANA
  • Why custom hierarchies matter


1. Key Terminologies-

Before diving into implementation, let‚Äôs clarify the basics:

  • Root Node : Top-most node in the hierarchy. Has No parent. Signifies the Hierarchy Structure and contains the Hierarchy metadata. A hierarchy can have several root nodes.
  • Hierarchy Node : Represents a group or element in the hierarchy.
  • Parent Node : A node that has child nodes beneath it.
  • Child Node : Belongs to a parent node.
  • Leaf Node : Lowest node in the hierarchy (end point).
  • Hierarchy Directory : Stores hierarchy definitions.
  • Siblings : Nodes sharing the same parent.
  • Hierarchy Level : Indicates depth of a node in the hierarchy. Levels can be defined as 0,1,2,3 . In S/4 EA change level based hierarchies to Parent child hierarchies .
  • Recursive Hierarchy: Nodes can reference themselves (e.g., Org Structure). Implemented using self-association in CDS.
  • Hierarchy Node Texts: These contain the descriptive names or labels associated with the hierarchy nodes, typically derived from the related master data (for example, the name or description of a General Ledger account or Product Hierarchy Description).
  • Orphan nodes, These are the nodes missing a link to a root. You can choose to ignore them, raise an error, or promote them as alternative roots using annotations like ORPHANS = ROOT

2. Example of a Hierarchy-

Company ‚Üí Product Category ‚Üí Product ‚Üí Variant Shoe Model 1

Example:

  • Company (ABC Corp)  ‚Üí Root Node -> The top most node in hierarchy (Defined via Hierarchy Directory and Root node has no parent defined)---- To be discussed in details in another Part 2.
  • Product Category (Footwear)  ‚Üí Child of Company->A Parent Node for Product but this is not the Root node(Since it has Company as a Parent Node).
  • Product (Shoes)  ‚Üí Child of Product Category->Parent Node for Variant
  • Variant (Shoe Model 1)  ‚Üí Leaf Node->Lowest Node in the hierarchy

 In SAP: For Cost Center or Profit Center hierarchy, Controlling Area could be the root node.

3. Types of Hierarchies in CDS Views-

In S/4HANA Embedded Analytics, hierarchies are modeled using CDS annotations. Most common type:

  • Parent-Child Hierarchy üîó Always recursive. Each node references its parent, forming a tree structure. Example: Cost Center hierarchy where each cost center belongs to a higher-level.

 

  • Level-Based Hierarchy üîóNot supported in S4 Hana Embedded analytics as Analytical engine supports only Parent Child Hierarchy for drill downs and aggregations.

CDS Annotation Example:

@Hierarchy.parentChild:
{ recurse:          {   parent: 'ParentNode',   child:  'HierarchyNode'   },
  siblingsOrder:    {   by: 'SequenceNumber',    direction: 'ASC'   },
  directory:        '_Hierarchy' }

4. Standard Hierarchies in S/4HANA-

SAP delivers several predefined hierarchies:

  • Cost Center Hierarchy ‚Äì For controlling and cost reporting
  • Profit Center Hierarchy ‚Äì For profitability analysis
  • GL Account Hierarchy ‚Äì For financial statements
  • Product Hierarchy ‚Äì For material classification
  • EHS Location Hierarchies ‚Äì For Environment, Health & Safety compliance

5. Custom Hierarchies-

Business requirements often demand custom hierarchies:

  • Example: A sales region hierarchy combining geography and product lines.
  • Implemented using CDS Views by developing a relation between Dimension Views and Hierarchy View.

6. Why Hierarchies Matter?

  • Enable drill-down reporting in SAC or Fiori Multidimensional Reports/AFO.
  • Support aggregations at multiple levels
  • Provide flexibility for planning and analytics

7. Technical Details: Where Hierarchies Are Stored-

  • HRRP_NODE_N Table: Stores Parent Node info, hierarchy node level details, and relationships between nodes(Example where GL Account/Profit Center/Cost Center Hierarchy details are stored).
  • HRRP_DIR_N Table: Stores Hierarchy Directory info (name, version, metadata).

üëâWhen you activate or create a hierarchy (standard or custom), these tables are updated.

  • HRRP_NODE_N = Node-level details (Parent-Child relationships)
  • HRRP_DIR_N = Directory-level details (Hierarchy header info)

8. Hierarchy Components & Annotations-

  • A well-defined hierarchy in CDS has multiple views:

Source(Master Data) View: Provides key fields and relationships (Eg GL Account/Cost Center/Product related details).
Hierarchy View: Contains the relationships and parent‚Äìchild links. Eg - Hierarchy(Child) Node, Parent Node, Node levels etc.
Directory View: Provides metadata about hierarchy variants -- Optional.
Text Views for labeling nodes and directory entries . Eg: GL account and it's text/ Cost center and it's text etc.

Proper annotations (@Hierarchy.parentChild, @ObjectModel.dataCategory: #HIERARCHY) control recursion, sibling order, orphan handling, and directory association

Notes:

  • Parent‚ÄìChild Hierarchy: Supported in CDS for analytics; recursive structure.
  • Level-Based Hierarchy: Not supported in CDS for analytical consumption (only parent‚Äìchild works for drill-down).
  • Orphan nodes = Nodes without a parent.
  • A Parent Node can have multiple Hierarchy Nodes/Child nodes but a hierarchy node cannot have multiple parents
  • A node can appear under different parents in different hierarchy versions, not in the same hierarchy( It usually refers to alternate hierarchy versions or variants, not simultaneous parents in the same hierarchy. For example:

Hierarchy Variant/Version 1: Region ‚Üí Country ‚Üí City

Hierarchy Variant/Version 2: Sales Channel ‚Üí Country ‚Üí City.This is managed via Hierarchy Directory.

  • A CDS hierarchy cannot serve as the underlying source for building another CDS hierarchy.

Next Article (Part 2)

  • How to activate Standard hierarchies and develop Custom Hierarchies in CDS Views (S4 Hana EA).
  • How to consume hierarchies in SAC

entry.title: SAP Certification Is Changing: What You Need to Know About the New Format
entry.content:
If you‚Äôve been following SAP‚Äôs certification updates, you‚Äôll know things are changing in a big way. The traditional multiple-choice exams are being replaced with a much more practical approach. I recently went through all the latest materials and sessions about the new SAP certification format, especially for SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC), and I want to share what I learned and how you can prepare.

Why Is SAP Changing Its Certification Format?

SAP wants certifications to mean more than just passing a test. The new format is designed to make sure certified professionals can actually do the work required on real SAP projects. Instead of just memorizing theory, you‚Äôll be asked to solve problems and perform tasks that you‚Äôd encounter in your day-to-day job. This shift is great news for both candidates and employers. Companies can trust that certified consultants are ready for hands-on work, and candidates can show they‚Äôre truly job-ready.

What‚Äôs Different About the New Exams?

The biggest change is the move to performance-based assessments. You‚Äôll be asked to complete tasks in a simulated SAP system, or respond to real-world scenarios, sometimes interacting with an AI avatar or submitting a video response. You can use SAP Help Portal, SAP Learning, and even SAP Joule (the AI tool) during the exam, just like you would on a real project. This open-book style makes the exam feel much more like actual work.

You also get to choose how you want to be assessed for some parts: either through an AI role-play or by uploading a video. After you finish, you‚Äôll receive instant feedback, including analytics on your technical depth and communication skills.

Role-Based Certifications and Staying Certified

SAP certifications are now tailored to specific job roles, such as developer, administrator, or architect. This means the exam content is more relevant to what you‚Äôll actually do in your role. Certifications aren‚Äôt permanent anymore. You‚Äôll need to complete a ‚Äústay-certified‚Äù assessment each year to keep your credential active. This helps ensure everyone stays up to date with the latest SAP technology and best practices.

Timeline for the New Format

The rollout starts in November 2025 for selected exams, including SAP BTP Administrator, SAP Build Developer, Solution Architect ‚Äì SAP BTP, SAP Business Data Cloud, and SAP Generative AI Developer. By 2026, all SAP certifications will use this new practical format.

What Hasn‚Äôt Changed?

You‚Äôll still get a digital badge when you pass, and the registration process is the same as before. If you already have a certification, it remains valid, but you‚Äôll need to follow the renewal process to keep it active.

How Should You Prepare?

Focus on building practical SAP skills. Spend time working in SAP simulation environments, and practice explaining SAP solutions clearly and simply. Get comfortable with timed tasks and AI evaluation, and make sure your laptop, internet, webcam, and audio all meet SAP‚Äôs technical requirements before exam day.

Spotlight on SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC) Certification

The BDC certification is a great example of the new approach. It covers foundational knowledge and practical skills in SAP Business Data Cloud. The assessment includes technical knowledge of BDC, integration with SAP Business Warehouse, SAP Analytics Cloud, SAP Datasphere, and SAP Databricks. To earn the badge, you‚Äôll need to complete the recommended SAP Learning Journey and pass the C_BCBDC exam. Remember to renew your badge every year.

Exam questions breakdown from my attempt:

 

  • Technical Knowledge of BDC (40%)
  • Integration with SAP Business Warehouse (15%)
  • Technical Knowledge of SAP Analytics Cloud (15%)
  • Technical Knowledge of SAP Datasphere (15%)
  • Technical Knowledge of SAP Databricks (15%)

 

Tips for Success

Take your time and use the pause button to think before you answer. Break your responses into clear chunks, and don‚Äôt worry about giving too much information, there‚Äôs no penalty for being thorough. Read the feedback you get and use it to improve before your next attempt. And don‚Äôt rush; you have plenty of time.

Useful Links

Here are some resources that helped me:

  • SAP Certification Overview
  • SAP Certification in the Age of AI
  • SAP BDC Learning Journey
  • SAP Certification BDC

Final Thoughts

SAP‚Äôs new certification format is a big step forward. It‚Äôs designed to make sure credentials really mean something and that certified professionals are ready for real project work. If you‚Äôre preparing for the SAP Business Data Cloud certification, focus on practical skills, clear communication, and continuous learning. The future of SAP certification is here, and it‚Äôs all about being ready for the real world.

If you have questions or want to share your experience with the new SAP certification, I‚Äôd love to hear from you in the comments.

entry.title: How to activate the Object Store in SAP Datasphere?
entry.content:
**Updated December 2025**

Symptom: You want to activate Object Store in SAP Datasphere, but you don't know how. 

Highlights:

  • You can create up to five spaces using the Object Store option.
  • Depending on your system, Object Store may take up to 1h to be available.
  • The deployment time for creating a file space can take some time (up to 45 min).
  • There is currently no ability to enable Object Store for existing spaces; you need to create a new one, named file space.
  • Downsizing SAP HANA Storage is not possible. It is only viable via deletion and recreation of your SAP Datasphere tenant.
  • There is no limitation regarding data center and region availability for Object Store: it is available in all data centers that SAP Datasphere is available on.  

Requirements:

  • Ensure you have at least 4151 Capacity Units (CU) for the tenant. For more information, click here.
  • Confirm that you are the system owner or have the DW Cloud Administrator role assigned to proceed with this action.
  • Make sure your SAP Datasphere tenant is on version 2021.03 or later. 

Resolution: 

1. Open your SAP Datasphere, log in, and open the navigation bar. 

2. Select "System", then click "Configuration". 

3. Go to the "Tenant Configuration" tab. 

4. In the "Base Configuration" card, select "Memory" for Performance Class. 

5. Increase Memory to 128GB and Storage to 384GB. 

6. In the ‚ÄúObject Store‚Äù card, set Storage to 1 TB, Compute to 1 Block-Hour, and Requests to 1,000 API Calls. If you need additional resources, feel free to adjust the Storage, Compute, and Requests values as needed.

7. Click "Save". 

8. Press "OK" if you agree with all statements regarding this upgrade. 

9. Wait 1h until Object Store is available. 

10. Go to "Space Management" and hit "Create".

11. Select "SAP HANA Data Lake Files" in Storage Type and press "Create". 

12. Now you have a space with Object Store enabled.

entry.title: IFRS 18 Explained: What SAP S/4HANA Customers Need to Know Before 2027
entry.content:
Spoiler
 

IFRS 18 introduces one of the biggest changes to financial statement presentation in decades, replacing IAS 1 and redefining how companies structure their Profit and Loss statements. This blog breaks down the new categories, required subtotals, MPM rules, and cash-flow changes in simple, human language ‚Äî and explains how SAP is preparing to support customers across S/4HANA Cloud, Private Edition, and On-Premise. With comparative reporting for 2026 and mandatory adoption from 2027, now is the time for finance and IT teams to understand what‚Äôs coming and how to prepare their SAP landscape.

What Is IFRS 18 and Why Is It Important?

IFRS 18 is a brand-new reporting standard released by the IASB. It replaces IAS 1 (Presentation of Financial Statements) and becomes effective on January 1, 2027.

In simple terms, IFRS 18 changes how companies present their Income Statement (P&L) and how they explain their financial performance.

Think of it as a cleaner, more structured way to show:

  • Where money comes from
  • Where it goes
  • What part of the business truly drives performance

The goal is to:

  • Make financial statements easier to understand
  • Improve consistency across companies
  • Increase transparency for investors
  • Make comparison between companies more fair and simple

What‚Äôs Changing in the Profit and Loss Statement? 

IFRS 18 completely reorganizes the Profit and Loss (P&L) structure.
Instead of mixing items together, companies must now classify every income and expense into new categories:

New Mandatory Categories

  • Operating: Day-to-day business activities
  • Investing: Returns or costs related to long-term investments
  • Financing: Borrowings, interest, and funding-related items
  • Income Tax: All tax-related items
  • Discontinued Operations: Business operations that are shut down or sold

New Required Subtotals

Companies must show these subtotals:

  • Operating Profit
  • Profit or Loss Before Financing and Income Tax
  • Profit or Loss

This improves clarity and avoids situations where different companies calculate ‚Äúoperating profit‚Äù differently.

What Are Management-Defined Performance Measures (MPMs)?

IFRS 18 introduces strict rules for something many companies already do:
show custom KPIs like ‚ÄúAdjusted EBITDA,‚Äù ‚ÄúCore Profit,‚Äù or ‚ÄúUnderlying Margin.‚Äù

These are called Management-Defined Performance Measures (MPMs).

Under IFRS 18, companies MUST:

  • Explain how the measure is calculated
  • Explain why it is useful
  • Provide a reconciliation to an official IFRS subtotal
  • Include this reconciliation in the notes, and it must be audited

This improves trust and transparency around custom metrics that companies use to tell their story.

Changes to the Cash Flow Statement

IFRS 18 also updates IAS 7 (Cash Flow Statements).
Previously, companies had flexibility in classifying certain cash flows.

Under IFRS 18:

  • Dividends paid ‚Üí must be shown under Investing activities
  • Interest paid ‚Üí must be shown under Financing activities
  • Interest received ‚Üí must be shown under Investing activities

This eliminates the old ‚Äúchoice-based‚Äù method and brings global consistency.

Impact on Financial Reporting and Disclosure

IFRS 18 affects several areas of financial reporting:

P&L Structure

Companies must reorganize their charts of accounts and reporting hierarchies.

Disclosures and Notes

More detail is required, especially around MPMs, aggregation rules, and reconciliation.

Comparative Reporting

Mandatory disclosure of 2026 figures in the new IFRS 18 structure when reporting for 2027.

What Does This Mean for Companies Using SAP?

SAP is currently analysing the full impact of IFRS 18 and consulting with customers through Customer Engagement Initiatives.

Key areas SAP is reviewing include:

  • Functional areas
  • General Ledger structure
  • Valuation processes
  • Reporting frameworks in S/4HANA
  • Group Reporting layouts
  • Cash-flow classifications
  • Universal Journal (ACDOCA) extensibility

SAP expects to release a formal solution approach by December 2025(as documented in SAP Note-https://me.sap.com/notes/3670330/E) . This guidance is expected to be included in the IFRS 18 updates for SAP Group Reporting as part of the 1SG content package.

The solution may differ across editions:

  • SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition
    ‚Üí Expect more standardized, pre-delivered content
  • SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition
    ‚Üí More flexibility with governance
  • SAP S/4HANA On-Premise
    ‚Üí Potentially greater configurability

SAP will deliver updates through notes, documentation, and future releases.

How Customers Can Prepare Today

Even before SAP finalizes its solution, companies can begin preparing by:

‚úî Reviewing current P&L structures
‚úî Identifying where income/expense items will map under IFRS 18
‚úî Understanding new disclosure requirements
‚úî Reviewing cash-flow classifications
‚úî Collecting internal MPM definitions
‚úî Engaging with SAP through CEI or Customer Influence Requests

Early preparation will make the transition smoother when IFRS 18 becomes mandatory.

Conclusion

IFRS 18 represents a major shift in how companies communicate their financial performance. The new structure, required subtotals, stricter rules for custom KPIs, and updates to cash flow presentation will significantly impact both finance teams and system configurations.

As outlined in SAP Note 3670330, SAP is developing a comprehensive solution targeted for late 2025, with further updates expected as IFRS 18 continues to evolve. In my view, this is the right time for organizations to start understanding the new requirements, assess their current data and reporting structures, and begin preparing their SAP landscapes for a smooth transition.

More updates will come as SAP refines its roadmap ‚Äî stay tuned.

entry.title: SAP Datasphere: How to define Offsets for Restriction Variables in Analytic Models
entry.content:
The definition of offsets for time characteristics like posting date, calendar month, fiscal period, etc. is a very common requirement when building queries for reporting. This blog post will show you a practical example how to implement this requirement in an analytic model instead of handling it in a view.

In this example, we have a fact view with the time characteristic "Year". This time characteristic is associated to the standard "Year" dimension of SAP:

The definition of offsets happens in another view, called "DeriveOffset". It constist of the key column "Year" of the standard time dimension and two calculated columns, "NextYear" and "PreviousYear". Furthermore it has an input parameter for the "CurrentYear", which filters the key column "Year". As a result, the view always returns one row with the "CurrentYear" and its previous and next value:

 

 

This view can be used as "Lookup Entity" in analytic models for restriction variables. When creating a restriction variable for restricted measures you can use the "DeriveOffset" view and choose the respective "Result Column". In this example it would be the "NextYear" column:

 

The "Lookup Entity Parameter Mapping" let's you decide, how the input parameter of the "Lookup Entity" should be filled. Here we choose "Map to" -> "New Variable":

Datasphere automatically creates a standard variable with the input parameter's name (here: "CurrentYear") of type manual input:

This standard variable can be reused for further restriction variables. In this example, further restriction variables are created with the same "Lookup Entity" but with different "Result Column", mapped to the same standard variable "CurrentYear":

The three restriction variables can be used to create restricted measures, in this example for the measure "GrossAmount":

 

As a result - when opening the preview - there is only one prompt for the current year, but the defined restricted measures are with the respective offset:

 

This basic example could further be enhanced by defining a "Dynamic Default" value for the standard variable, or it could also be of the type "Derive Value" filled with values of a central view/table. The DeriveOffset view could be enhanced with more offset columns or a further cascading derivation logic could be implemented. In general, I think the derivation features have great potential when designing analytic models and the ability to use it for restriction variables closes gaps compared to BW queries. From architecture perspective, it should be considered to design derivation views in a centralized way, especially for common requirements like offsets for time characteristics.

entry.title: SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC): A Beginner's Guide - Part 2
entry.content:
Introduction

This is an SAP blog series on SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC). This is the second part of the blog series SAP Business Data Cloud - A Beginner's Guide. If you missed the first part please go through that and let me know your feedback or comments. 

SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC): A Beginner's Guide - Part 1 

In the first part, I covered Introduction to SAP Business Data Cloud, Why do we need SAP Business Data Cloud, and Key Components of SAP Business Data Cloud. I hope you have got a basic understanding about SAP Business Data Cloud from the first part. 

In this part, I'm planning to cover the Architecture of SAP Business Data Cloud in beginner's language. 

Architecture of SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC)

SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC) architecture consists of:

  1. Source Systems
  2. Foundation Services
  3. SAP Datasphere
  4. SAP Databricks
  5. SAP BW and BW/4 HANA
  6. SAP Analytics Cloud
  7. Intelligent Applications
  8. BDC Cockpit

How the Architecture fits together

Let's understand how the architecture fits together end-to-end. 

The data journey starts with Source Systems. It can be both Cloud and On-Prem sources. It can be both SAP and non-SAP systems. SAP S/4HANA. SAP SuccessFactors, ECC, Ariba, and Concur are just a few examples. These systems provide the raw business data for e.g, things like transactions, employees, vendors, or purchase orders.

From there, that data moves into Foundation Services, which harmonize and transform it into unified data products. Those data products are then modeled and governed in SAP Datasphere, where they can be used for analytics, planning, and machine learning.

If the organization needs advanced AI or large-scale data processing, that‚Äôs where SAP Databricks comes into play. It can extend your data models using pro-code data science tools and then push enriched results back into the Business Data Cloud environment.

SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) then takes over for data visualization and dashboards, and planning which allows business users to explore insights interactively. It‚Äôs the front-end planning and analytics face of the platform for most end users.

Now, all of this is orchestrated and managed through the SAP Business Data Cloud Cockpit. The cockpit is essentially your control center. It‚Äôs where you can browse pre-delivered data products, install intelligent applications, manage data sharing with Databricks, and configure access and roles. For administrators, this is where most of the setup and system management happens.

Finally, we have the SAP Business Data Cloud Intelligent Applications. These are SAP-managed SaaS apps built on the platform that address specific use cases like predictive forecasting, anomaly detection, or scenario-based analytics. They use all the underlying components SAP Datasphere, SAP Databricks, SAP Analytics Cloud to deliver a ready made intelligence to business users.

So when you look at the architecture as a whole, it‚Äôs really a layered ecosystem:

  1. Source systems provide the data
  2. Foundation Services manage and transform it.
  3. SAP Datasphere models and governs it.
  4. SAP Databricks adds AI and ML.
  5. SAP Analytics Cloud visualises and plans it.
  6. Cockpit and Intelligent Applications tie it all together into a complete end-to-end experience.

What makes this architecture so powerful is that everything is connected. Data flows seamlessly from operational systems into analytics and AI without losing trust, structure, or meaning.

 

Conclusion

In this blog we covered the architecture of SAP Business Data Cloud and How it fits together everything. This is the part 2 of the SAP Business Data Cloud - A beginner's guide series.

In case if you missed the part 1, here is the link to it.  SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC): A Beginner's Guide - Part 1  - Please go through it and let me know if you have any comments or feedbacks.

In the next part of the series, we will deep dive into the main components and it's role in SAP BDC. 

If you have any feedback, questions or queries, please post them as comments. I will try to answer the maximum as per my knowledge.

entry.title: Fast-track AI-driven Insights with Zero-Copy Data Access between SAP BDC and Google BigQuery
entry.content:
SAP launched SAP Datasphere with its business data fabric architecture and open data ecosystem in 2023, with Google as one of its first partners. Since then, we‚Äôve continued helping customers drive innovation with a data and analytics strategy that unifies SAP data and analytics with the strengths of Google Cloud‚Äôs BigQuery platform.  

Building on this partnership, we recently announced SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC) Connect for Google BigQuery at SAP Connect 2025, further strengthening our collaboration and enabling secure, zero-copy data access to curated SAP data products directly from BigQuery. SAP BDC Connect for Google BigQuery is planned to be generally available by the end of H1 2026. 

With SAP BDC Connect for BigQuery, organizations can build a business data fabric and connect their existing Google BigQuery environments to #SAP Business Data Cloud‚Äîoffering data and AI teams real-time access to semantically rich SAP data products without the duplication or operational burden of multiple ETL pipelines. SAP BDC Connect for BigQuery will also be bidirectional, so organizations can break silos and democratize data with an ecosystem of business-ready data products exchanged between SAP BDC and Google Cloud Cortex Framework in BigQuery. This milestone reflects a clear architectural transformation, unlocking the potential of enterprise data for analytics and AI innovation. 

 In this blog, we take a sneak-peek into the technology behind this integration and offer prescriptive guidance with reference architectures for building seamless data integration between SAP Business Data Cloud and Google Cloud‚Äôs data and AI solutions. 

Fig 1 : SAP BDC ‚Äì GBQ Integration reference architecture.  

SAP BDC Connect for BigQuery will enable seamless, secure data sharing between SAP BDC and Google BigQuery‚Äîsimplifying customer landscapes and accelerating AI-driven insights and innovation.  

Third-party data, such as Google Cloud‚Äôs Weather, Trends, Geo, and Ads, can then be effortlessly integrated and harmonized with valuable SAP data like finance and supply chain. Leveraging open data protocols and advanced data fabric architectures, this approach will simplify data sharing and unify access to information across multiple systems in a heterogenous landscape. The result will be a centrally governed, holistic data environment that supports efficient analytics and AI/ML-driven use cases‚Äîall built on industry-standard open protocols.  

Challenges addressed by SAP BDC Connect for BigQuery:  

This new zero-copy integration with BigQuery aims to solve challenges caused by data duplication copies.  

  • Loss of governance: Data governance becomes a major challenge once data is replicated and siloed into multiple disparate systems.  
  • Loss of valuable semantics: Data extracted from business applications loses its critical semantics and business context, making it incredibly difficult to rebuild accurately and leading to issues in data quality. 
  • High total cost of ownership (TCO) : Managing ETL pipelines with expensive third-party tools adds operational complexity and overhead, elevating the total cost of ownership (TCO) across the data landscape. 
  • Innovation delays: Complex and fragile data pipelines hinder organizational agility, delays the delivery of actionable business insights, and restrict the pace of AI innovation and data-driven initiatives. 

Key differentiating capabilities that will be introduced by the SAP BDC Connect for BigQuery architecture include: 

  • Access to AI-ready data: Accelerate AI-driven insights by combining Google Cloud's Vertex AI capabilities and analytics tools with curated, AI-ready SAP data products securely shared and governed directly from SAP Business Data Cloud.  
  • Unified Data View: Deliver a harmonized view by integrating SAP data and third-party data across Google BigQuery and SAP Business Data Cloud without duplication. Build a unified, semantically rich data foundation to fuel next-gen data and AI/ML workloads using SAP Joule, Google Vertex AI, and Google Cortex framework. 
  • Bi-directional data sharing: Share data products bi-directionally between SAP Business Data Cloud and Google BigQuery via their respective catalogs. This enables interoperability and re-use of these blended data sets  and derived data products . 
  •  Delta Sharing protocol: Leverage bidirectional data integration between SAP BDC and BigQuery, powered by the combination of industry open standards such as Delta Sharing open data protocol and other open table formats. This enables real-time interoperability across different computing platforms, cloud environments, and applications without duplicating data. 
  • Opens up flexible infrastructure choices: Leverage the highly scalable infrastructure of Google BigQuery , and powerful enterprise analytics capabilities of SAP Business Data Cloud to handle large volumes of data and complex analytics workloads. Share data products from Google BigQuery back to SAP BDC for analytics and planning in SAP Analytics Cloud and AI solutions with SAP Business AI as well.  
  • Governed and secure data exchange: Provide a secure and governed experience with enhanced control over data shared via centralized access, managed by data stewardship roles. BDC Connect leverages security protocols such as mutual Transport Layer Security (mTLS) and OpenID Connect (OIDC) to ensure safe data exchanges 
  • Increased scalability and data exchange speed: With the zero-copy integration,  the bottleneck of slow data transfers (as seen with data federation architecture) will be solved SAP BDC Connect that offers efficient data sharing at great scale than before.    

 The technical integration (SAP BDC Connect for Google BigQuery) enables powerful, AI-driven use cases across these business functions, detailed in the sources as strategic focuses for the partnership.

 

Business Function Use Cases Enabled 
Supply Chain & Operations Predictive Inventory Optimization: Combining live SAP inventory data with marketing campaign data (e.g., TikTok, Meta, Google Ads) and external signals like weather data or Google Trends for demand forecasting. 
 AI-Powered Logistics: Integrating SAP order and fulfillment data with external data (like GPS/traffic) to optimize delivery routes and predict delays.
 Enhanced Demand Forecasting: Using machine learning to analyze historical SAP sales data combined with market trends and promotions. 

Marketing 

Cross-Channel Campaign Optimization: Combining SAP customer sales history with audience data (e.g., LiveRamp) and campaign performance from Google Ads, YouTube, Meta, and TikTok to optimize spend and ROI. 
 Personalized Marketing Campaigns: Using enriched SAP customer and product data to create highly personalized campaigns on platforms like Google Ads and social media. 
Sales & Service 360-Degree Customer View: Consolidating customer data from SAP (billing, service history) with sales data (Salesforce) and service interactions (ServiceNow). 
Manufacturing Unified IT/OT Data for AI: Ingesting granular asset-level data from the shop floor (OT data) and sensor data and combining it with enterprise (IT) data for Manufacturing to improve productivity. 
 Production Optimization: Gaining cross-enterprise intelligence by tracking marketing campaigns to inform product demand, production, and staffing. 
Finance & Analytics Build Grounded, Trustworthy AI: Ensuring that Google BigQuery AI models and agents operate on the most current and complete view of the business using real-time SAP data. 
Sustainability ESG Reporting and Optimization: Integrating sustainability data from SAP with other external data sources to create a unified view for comprehensive reporting and using AI to analyze energy consumption or carbon emissions. 

 

Enhancing and scaling use cases with SAP BDC connect for Google BigQuery  

This expanded partnership also allows us to enhance previous SAP Datasphere and BigQuery use cases. While FedML successfully enabled machine-learning use cases on Google Cloud Platform using SAP data, further scaling was necessary to support data at larger volumes. Users could also replicate data to Google BigQuery using SAP Datasphere replication flows.  For example, analyzing historical SAP sales data alongside market trends and promotions typically required either replicating the data needed‚Äîcomplex, costly, and time-consuming‚Äîor using connector-based data federation, which is faster but less scalable.  

Now, SAP BDC Connect for Google BigQuery provides a simpler, secure, and scalable option with one-click, zero-copy data sharing via BDC catalog. This eliminates the need for data duplication , reduces data access delays usually seen with federated access, and ensures secure and governed data access (which was missing with service user-based connectors). 

In summary, the zero-copy architecture enabled by BDC Connect for Google BigQuery addresses business challenges with greater speed, lower cost, improved quality, enhanced security, and unprecedented scale.

The above reference architectures are the results of teamwork and contributions from both SAP and Google. I would like to thank the following SAP team members for their contribution to this content  : Kevin Poskitt, Katryn Cheng, Mariusz Cisek, San Tran And  Sivakumar N,  Anirban Majumdar, Haridas Nair for their support and guidance. We also extend special thanks to the Google team members who helped assemble the guiding use-case list.

entry.title: SAP Datasphere & Google BigQuery: 3 Integration Strategies Before Zero Copy via BDC Connect Arrives
entry.content:
Hello guys, how are you?

SAP and Google announced at the last SAP Connect that in H1-2026 we will have Zero Copy using BDC connect between SAP Business Data Cloud and Google BigQuery.

 

Today, our Databricks zero-copy strategy is powered by Delta Sharing. This technology, created by Databricks, enables the secure and rapid sharing of data stored in Delta Lake without the need for file replication.

What is Delta Share / Zero Copy ?

Imagine you have a Data Lake (full of Parquet, CSV, JSON files, etc.).

Then someone comes along and says

"Hey, I need access to this data!"

Normally, you would have to:

  • send the files (copies),
  • or grant access to the storage,
  • or create an API.

Delta Share / Zero Copy simplifies this:

It allows you to share data directly from Delta Lake, in Delta Table format, without moving the files. The recipient of access can read the data live, as if it were a local table ‚Äî and with:

  • security (permission control),
  • consistency (no one gets corrupted or incomplete data),
  • and automatic updates (if the data changes, the consumer sees the updated version).

We can find more information about Zero Copy with Google BigQuery at this link : https://news.sap.com/2025/10/sap-google-cloud-redefine-enterprise-ai-zero-copy-data-google-bigquery/

However, until this connector is available, we can currently use three methods to integrate SAP Datasphere and Google Big Query, which are:

  • Data Federation: Google BigQuery -> SAP Datasphere
  • Data Federation: SAP Datasphere -> Google BigQuery
  • SAP HANA ML or FED ML in Jupyter Notebooks embedded in Google BigQuery

First, what is data federation?

Data federation is an approach that allows access to and querying of information stored in different sources without needing to move or duplicate that data to a single repository. Instead of making copies, federation creates a virtual layer that connects systems and allows data to be consumed in real time, directly from its origins. In the context of SAP Datasphere, data federation allows the integration of external platforms‚Äîsuch as Google BigQuery, AWS Athena, or Azure Synapse‚Äîkeeping the data where it is, but with the ability to combine and analyze it along with information from the SAP ecosystem. This approach reduces redundancies, improves governance, and ensures always up-to-date access to information, without sacrificing performance and security.

1. Data Federation : Google Big Query ->  SAP Datasphere

The federation between SAP Datasphere and Google BigQuery allows you to access BigQuery data directly in SAP Datasphere without replicating the data, creating virtual tables that aggregate data from different sources without duplicating them. (link : https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-members/data-federation-in-datasphere/ba-p/13750166 )

Example : 

A common scenario would be a company that has transactional data in SAP S/4HANA and market analysis data in Google BigQuery. Through federation, you can create views that combine sales data from SAP with market trend data from BigQuery, enabling integrated analysis without moving the data from their original locations. The result is a unified view of the data that can be consumed by SAP Analytics Cloud for visualizations and reporting.

 

Below are some steps to use this architecture:

1 - Configure Google BigQuery in SAP Datasphere.

2 - Select the table from SAP BigQuery and import its metadata into SAP Datasphere.

3 - Creating a model by combining data from SAP Datasphere and Google BigQuery.

 

Here at the Discovery Center, you have a step-by-step guide on how to configure and access Google BigQuery data federation in SAP Datasphere. https://discovery-center.cloud.sap/missiondetail/3409/?tab=projectboard

Advantages of this approach

  1. Unified analytics - You combine BigQuery data with SAP information (ERP, BW, HANA, etc.) in a single analytical environment.
  1. No data movement - SAP Datasphere accesses data directly from BigQuery‚Äîno copies, ETL, or extra storage costs.
  1. Real-time access - Queries reflect the most recent BigQuery data, always up-to-date.
  1. Preserved governance and security - Google Cloud access and control rules remain in effect, ensuring end-to-end security.
  1. Use of the SAP ecosystem - Allows you to use SAP Datasphere resources (modeling, Data Marketplace, SAP semantics) with BigQuery data.
  2. Scalability and performance - SAP Datasphere leverages BigQuery performance for federated queries on large volumes of data.
  3. Simpler and more flexible architecture - Fewer integrations and pipelines‚Äîyou choose when to federate or, if you prefer, materialize the data in SAP.

2.  Data Federation :  SAP Datasphere -> Google Big Query

This approach to data federation between SAP Datasphere and Google BigQuery allows you to access data from SAP Datasphere directly in Google BigQuery without replicating the data, or, if you prefer, materializing the data in SAP.

For this approach, we configured a federated SAP HANA connection in Google BigQuery with these steps:

Step 1 - Create a user database in an SAP Datasphere space

Step 2 - Enable the "Expose for consumption" toggle in the SAP Datasphere view

Step 3 - Create the federated connection within Google BigQuery

3.  SAP HANA ML or FED ML in Jupyter Notebooks embedded in Google Big Query

In this approach, we can transform a table or query from SAP Datasphere into a dataframe directly in Google BigQuery.

What are these libraries?

Firstly, hana-ml library is a Python client library that allows data scientists to access SAP HANA data and build machine learning models using the data directly in SAP HANA, without needing to move data between the server and the client. The library provides a Python interface to SAP HANA's machine learning capabilities, including access to the Predictive Analysis Library (PAL) and Automated Predictive Library (APL) algorithms. (https://pypi.org/project/hana-ml/)

FED ML, or Federated Machine Learning, is a Python library developed to solve a specific problem: connecting SAP business data to external Artificial Intelligence environments (Hyperscalers) efficiently and without excessive duplication. This library allows Data Scientists to work on platforms like AWS SageMaker, Azure ML, or Google Vertex AI, using open-source libraries (such as TensorFlow, PyTorch, or Scikit-learn), consuming data directly from SAP Datasphere without the need to create complex ETL (Extraction, Transformation, and Loading) pipelines. (https://github.com/SAP-samples/datasphere-fedml ).
